newsitem.title: UK: Forth Ports to push ahead with Mersey plans.
newsitem.headline: Forth Ports to push ahead with Mersey plans.

text.p: Forth Ports Plc today said it is likely to push ahead with plans to build a ferry terminal near Liverpool despite being rejected grant aid by the European Union.

Forth Ports chief executive Alistair Fleming told Reuters: "Our application for 4 million sterling aid to construct a terminal on the River Mersey at Birkenhead was based on throughput predictions by our principals."
"They have now guaranteed higher levels of throughput so revenues will be higher than we expected and the terminal makes even more economic sense."
Fleming added that the grant application was turned down by the European Union because aid was judged likely to distort competition.
The company had earlier said in a statement it was reviewing its position through discussions with potential partners following the rejection of grant aid for the terminal.
Forth Ports submitted a Harbour Empowerment Order for the terminal to the Department of Transport last year.
The company said three objections were received, and the DoT decided to hold a public inquiry this May into its proposals. Forth Ports added it had responded to the objections.
Fleming said the main opposition had come from Mersey Docks and Harbour Co which has rival plans for a terminal on the other side of the River Mersey.

He added that he believed there was sufficient long term potential for two terminals on the Mersey as traffic was growing rapidly across the Irish Sea. -- Paul Berrill Reuters Shipping News + Tel 171 542 4087
